perturbation.original_text: i-Escrow shall keep for one (1) year proper records and books of account relating to the computation of advertising payments owed to 2TheMart (including, as appropriate, the computation of the size of average Transaction). Once every twelve (12) months, 2TheMart through a CPA may inspect and audit such records to verify reports. Any such inspection will be conducted in a manner that does not unreasonably interfere with i-Escrow's business activities and with no less than fifteen (15) days notice. i-Escrow shall within two (2) weeks make any overdue payments disclosed by the audit.
perturbation.changed_text: i-Escrow shall keep records and books of account relating to the computation of advertising payments owed to 2TheMart (including, as appropriate, the computation of the size of average Transaction) for only six (6) months. 2TheMart may inspect and audit such records to verify reports, but only with five (5) days' notice. i-Escrow shall, within one (1) month, make any overdue payments disclosed by the audit.
perturbation.explanation: This change reduces the record-keeping period, shortens the audit notice period, and extends the payment deadline after the audit, potentially violating California's requirements for maintaining accurate financial records and timely payments.
perturbation.law_explanation: California Corporations Code Section 1502 requires corporations to maintain accurate records. Reducing the record-keeping period to six months may not be sufficient to ensure compliance with this requirement, especially if audits or legal inquiries occur after that period. The reduction in notice for audits and the extended payment period also impede the ability to promptly verify and rectify any payment discrepancies.

(a) Every corporation shall file, within 90 days after the filing of its original articles and annually thereafter during the applicable filing period, on a fo

perturbation.original_text: A party wishing to renew this Agreement shall give the other party notice thereof no less than thirty (30) days before the expiration of the term then in effect. In the event that either party does not give such notice, the term of this Agreement shall be automatically renewed for another one (1) year.
perturbation.changed_text: A party wishing to renew this Agreement shall give the other party notice thereof no less than ten (10) days before the expiration of the term then in effect. In the event that either party does not give such notice, the term of this Agreement shall be automatically renewed for another one (1) year.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the renewal notice period to ten days may be insufficient for the other party to adequately assess the contract's performance and negotiate renewal terms, potentially conflicting with the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing under California law.
perturbation.law_explanation: California Commercial Code Section 1304 states that every contract or duty within the Commercial Code imposes an obligation of good faith in its performance and enforcement. Reducing the notice period to 10 days may violate this covenant, as it might not provide sufficient time for a party to evaluate the agreement's performance, seek legal counsel, and negotiate terms for renewal. This could amount to a lack of good faith in the performance of the agreement.

GENERAL PROVISIONS [1101 - 1310] ( Division 1 enacted by Stats. 1963, Ch. 819. ) CHAPTER 3. Territorial Applicability and General Rules [1301 - 1310] ( Chapter 3 added by Stats. 2006, Ch. 254, Sec. 30. ) 1304. Every contract or duty within this code imposes an obligation of good faith in its performance and enforcement. (Added by renumbering Section 1203 by Stats. 2006, Ch. 254, Sec. 19. Effective January 1, 2007.)

perturbation.original_text: Upon expiration or termination of this Agreement, within fourteen (14) days of the other party's request, each party will return all Confidential Information and other deliverables to the requesting party.
perturbation.changed_text: Upon expiration or termination of this Agreement, each party will retain the other party's confidential information at their discretion.
perturbation.explanation: This eliminates the obligation to return confidential information, conflicting with standard practices for protecting trade secrets under California law.
perturbation.law_explanation: The California Uniform Trade Secrets Act (CUTSA) provides remedies for the misappropriation of trade secrets. By removing the requirement to return confidential information upon termination, the modified clause increases the risk of trade secret misappropriation, potentially contradicting CUTSA. If a party were to use the retained information to their advantage, it could lead to legal action under CUTSA.
